ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture
Synchronous Zoom seminars, Canvas discussion boards, Office hours
Virtual seminars complemented by a weekly recorded lecture.
The course also included a weekly virtual lecture, but this was asynchronous.
There were weekly lectures to complement our discussions, hosted by a variety of professors. Our section met three times weekly with our professor, for a small seminar class.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learning early philosophy and how to meaningfully engage in seminars
I became a better speaker and learned how to think about the world in an entirely different way.
Textual analysis, ability to engage in verbal discussion and debate of central philosophical texts and principles, improved written analysis and clarity
I learned how to write a philosophical reconstruction and greatly improved by analytical reading skills.

I learned how to write a philosophical paper, which is something that was never required during my high school experience and is distinct from an english essay. My close reading skills also improved, because many of the texts included required multiple read-throughs before I understood them.
How to critically think about philosophers

This was an amazing class! Through reading philosophical works and writing analyses/evaluations of them, my writing and thinking has greatly developed. Theres a strong emphasis on conciseness and clarity, which is applicable to all subjects. Amazing for getting insights on the foundations of philosophy, as well as being able to put schools of thought into discussion and debate.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only weakness of this course is that it was online. I absolutely loved this course.

Strengths: Professor Harte is by far my favorite instructor of my fall semesterengaged, approachable, clear, available. She has improved my writing and speaking tenfold. Could not have asked for a better introduction to philosophy.

I found this course to be very strong. Professor Harte was a fantastic professor. Her explanations of difficult concepts were clear and concise. Her feedback on papers was helpful and returned quickly. All around a fantastic class.

This was my favorite course of my first semester at Yale, so the strengths are what stood out. The discussions were always interesting, and nearly everyone in the class was engaged, which helped create a great learning environment. While my classmates were all quite smart, they were also kind and unpretentious, so there was never any of the one-upmanship that arose in my other seminars.
Very good books, would have liked more student-student discourse.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminars worked quite well - the problems mainly arose out of connection issues that often caused us to end class early or miss out on valuable discussion material.

The best modes of instruction were certainly the synchronous Zoom seminars and office hours with Professor Harte. The Canvas discussion threads were, at time, redundant to what would be discussed in class.

I found this class to be successful despite the challenges created by the covid pandemic. Professor Harte's email communication improved across the semester; but ensuring frequent email communication is my main comment.
I think this class succeeded even while online due to the small class size. This meant the awkwardness of zoom was somewhat mitigated.

The professor made a clear effort to reach out to the students and make sure the teaching style was effective. Asked for insights midway through the semester, and was often open to advice or suggestions from us. Overall, very enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Professor Harte is FANTASTIC and the material is so interesting. Completely changed the way that I think.

I would recommend this course to a peer with the highest regard. Professor Harte allows these abstract philosophical texts to be incredibly approachable and creates a welcoming and academically rigorous seminar environment. Written feedback is top notch as well.
I have found the Directed Studies program to be fantastic and deeply enjoyable. I would recommend to every student, regardless of background or future plans.

Certainly. I had little interest in philosophy before taking the course, and I still do not think it is something that I want to major in, but I was able to get a lot out of the class. The skills I gained in regards to tackling difficult texts will be applicable for all humanities courses.
Yes. The stuff you learn is good to know.

Definitely! I absolutely loved it, and think its a perfect introductory course to philosophy through its focus on Ancient thinkers. However, it requires a clear interest in the subject, and a willingness to devote time and effort into the readings.
